direction.raw_text: . HOUSE - NIGHT 1 From a distance and through the trees we see a raging hell fire engulfing a small two story house. It burns and burns. Out of nowhere a man bursts through a second story window, lands hard and rolls to smother his burning clothes. He crawls away and staggers up and for a moment looks as if he might run back into the flames. But the heat is unbearable. He runs toward us then past us through black shadows. We cannot see his face,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WINDOW - EARLY MORNING (WINTER 1930S) 1A Glass in a weathered window glitters with early morning sun. A rock shatters one of the remaining glass panes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . YARD - EARLY MORNING/CONTINUOUS 2 The rock thrower, TOM ( 10) is hightailing it away from an isolated Appalachian SHACK as the door bangs open, a shotgun barrel appears, and a chicken comes SQUAWKING out from under the porch! Thinking he's sure to be shot, Tom runs into the old barn!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S BARN - EARLY MORNING/CONTINUOUS 3 Panting in terror, Tom is hunkered down in strips of light, trying to see through the cracks. There is a loud SNORT and the huge face of some kind of beast suddenly appears at his shoulder. Tom jumps, panicked, just as a SHADOWY FIGURE creeps into the barn and levels a glinting shotgun at him! Tom freezes, bends over, and throws up! When Tom looks up, a ray of light reveals the half face of a fierce gray bearded man, FELIX BUSH. He is holding out a handkerchief to the boy. Shaking hard, Tom hesitates then takes it and wipes his mouth. Bush pushes open the door and gives Tom a sad look that the boy will never forget before waving him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S BARN - MORNING 4 Looking back over his shoulder, Tom runs for the road. Two of his BUDDIES are already kicking up dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: steps into the sun and watches the boy run off with a look of muted anger, sadness, and something much deeper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S BARN - DAY 5 Bush enters the barn to check on his companion. MULE is older than Bush in mule years and just as gray. He wears an old mule blanket everywhere to keep out the cold. He fidgets nervously from all the excitement. Bush comforts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a boy, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 7 Bush rips down an old faded sign at the road and posts a 7 fresh one:'No Damn Trespassing/Beware of Mule'. Bush checks the road in both directions. All clear for now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bush splits firewood with powerful cleaving strokes. Mule 8 dozes in the shade. Bush sees a Model-T approach and turn into his road, right past his new sign. He glances at his shotgun leaning against the shack. The Model-T comes to a shaky stop. A MAN climbs out, sees Bush swinging the axe and approaches with trepidation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mornin', sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hard life if you can't read..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pardon? I'm uh, Reverend Gus Horton, sir, how you doing? Bush stops his swing and turns and stares coldly at Horton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't need saving, preacher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh, well, Mr. Wiley Starke has passed on, sir. His funeral is tomorrow and I thought you might want to know since..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What got him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just got old, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well.. Bush returns to chopping wood. Feeling awkward, Horton hesitates, starts for his car, stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Starke told me that you and him ran away from home when you were 6 years old. Is that true?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I talked him into it. Bush doesn't turn, just keeps chopping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well.. anyway.. I.. alright.. Horton shrugs, get in his car, and leaves. Bush strikes the log hard and a cleaved piece goes flying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CEMETERY - EVENING 9 The loneliness of the empty cemetery is broken by Wiley Starke's fresh grave. The mounded earth is covered with beautiful flowers and wreathes, a loving send off from his family and friends. As we pan past the flowers and cards.. we realize that the cemetery is not quite empty. Hunkered down nearby, Bush is as still as a gravestone, staring at the last resting place of his old friend. As Bush gets up to leave he stops abruptly and stands frozen, staring at a pot of YELLOW FLOWERS on a distant grave. Now he turns and walks quickly away in the opposite direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S SHACK - NIGHT 10 Rain drums hard on the tin roof as Bush, soaked to the bone and shaking with chills, rummages through an old hat box by lamp light: Letters, news clippings and keepsakes. He finds what he's looking for: A PICTURE of a BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOMAN. She smiles at us from happier days. Realizing that he is raging with a serious fever, he tries to stand up only to collapse back on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S SHACK - NIGHT 14 Wrapped in his quilt and carrying the oil lamp, Bush moves slowly toward the barn. But he is so wracked with fever he has to stop. It stuns him that he can't go on. He never thought anything could stop him. Stuck in the rain with the shaking lamp sizzling, he stares into the forever darkness, the muscles in his jaw rippling in the pale light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well hell..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S BARN - NIGHT 15 Somehow he has made it. Sopping wet and shivering, Bush is in bad shape and knows it. Mule sees Bush and grunts anxiously as he rises. Bush blindly pours Mule some feed and the poor old thing snatches his first meal in days. Bush tries to think through the fever. He stumbles back to the door and swings it wide open so Mule can get out if Bush doesn't make it. Satisfied, he comes back and drops hard onto a pile of hay near Mule.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always thought you'd go first.. White as cotton, Bush stares into the lamp that is running out of oil, the light fading fast to darkness. Thoughts tumble through his mind, troubling him, stirring the dark waters of memory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S BARN - MORNING 16 PAN across the stillness of the foothills to the barn. The door is still swung wide open. Back from the brink of death, Bush emerges into the blinding sunlight. Mule is dozing in his favorite spot. He swings his big gray head over at Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ahh, don't look so disappointed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S BARN - MORNING 18 Mule watches Bush heave a creaky old wagon out from behind the barn. Mule climbs up on all fours. Bush gets a set of reins and walks toward him. Mule starts to take a stroll, knowing what the reins mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better not. Mule looks back, sees an apple in Bush's hand, and stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And coffee when we get there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAIN STREET - DAY 19 Old wheels creak and moan. Bush and Mule ease up Main street with the cart. PEOPLE try to catch a glimpse of the infamous recluse. Mule comes to a wearied stop, breathing hard. Bush climbs off the cart and walks Mule, ignoring the eyes upon him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHAPEL - DAY 20 Reverend Horton, stoking the wood stove, hears FOOTSTEPS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buddy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . But as he turns he sees Bush silently looking around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh! Hello.. Horton comes to Bush but Bush ignores him and keeps critically looking around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What can I do for you, sir? Suddenly BUDDY and KATHRYN ROBINSON (20's) enter from the vestibule with their new BABY. In their own world, and not realizing that there is anyone in the chapel, Kathryn picks some lint from Buddy's jacket. He catches her fingers and kisses them. Bush is transfixed by the loving moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can wait. Buddy and Kathryn see Horton and double-take Bush. Buddy nods to Horton and he and Kathryn step back into the vestibule to give Bush and Horton privacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's alright, have a seat. Bush sits down uneasily in a pew. Horton sits down in the pew in front of him and twists around to face him. The wintry light from the near window washes over them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's on your mind, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bout time for me to get low.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Down to business Bush reaches into his overalls and puts a balled-up wad of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the pew. Horton's eyes bulge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Need a funeral. Horton looks up from the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me. Buddy peers around from the vestibule, listening, curious as hell, until Kathryn pulls him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For you? (off Bush's impatient nod) You want to buy a funeral for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I not talking right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, yes, I'm sorry. Are you sick sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody dies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True, but..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't take care of my bones it won't get done, will it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, I see. Well the church can help you get your affairs in order, arrange a service.. Horton glances at the strange wad of money again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What would you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A eulogy? I.. don't know. What do you want me to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say what you'd say right now to my face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. I uh, I don't know much about you, Mr. Bush. I mean, I've heard stories but..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What stories? Bush leans in and stares into Horton. It feels like everything in the world stops dead. Buddy peeks in again, this time Kathryn peeks too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just stories.. (off Bush's intense look) .you know, people talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of stories? Say one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir.. my mother used to say that gossip is the devil's radio.. (UNFORTUNATE ASIDE) .not that she didn't play that radio at full volume now and then, bless her heart, but.. (back to business) .what matters when you come to the end of your life is that you're ready for the next one. Have you made peace with God, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I paid. Horton has no idea what Bush means. He looks at the money, back at Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well.. you can't buy forgiveness, Mr. Bush. It's free. But you do have to ask for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing in this world is free, preacher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Bush abruptly grabs his money and starts out. His hand bangs into the pew and the money FALLS. Buddy stares wild-eyed at the big wad of money then drops back into the vestibule. Bush storms past Buddy, Kathryn and the baby like a hot wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHURCH - DAY 20A Bush heads off down the road on his wagon. Horton, Buddy, and Kathryn appear at the door and watch him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was, uh, different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard such awful things about him when I was a kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother probably told you some of them. Kathryn goes back into the church with Horton who is cooing at the baby. Buddy lingers, staring at Bush, thinking..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAIN STREET - DAY 21 Bush's wagon loaded with bags of feed and supplies, sits in front of the Diner. Bush is holding a big tin cup of coffee for Mule who is drinking it and loving it. Tom (the kid who threw the rock) comes from behind the diner with a full garbage can to empty into the big trash barrels on the back of an old pick-up truck. He sees Bush and freezes. Bush looks up and stares at him. The diner door snaps open and BONNIE (30's), Tom's mother, steps out. She sees Tom and Bush staring at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing, son? Now Tom is scared to death that Bush is going to tell on him. Bonnie doesn't like this staring match at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Empty those cans in your daddy's truck and get back in here. Now. Finally Bush drops his gaze and lets Tom off the hook. Relieved, Tom heaves the can up into the truck. Bonnie hesitates then goes back into the diner just as... .CARL (30s), his sidekick, GARY, and two other MEN come across the street toward the diner. Gary sees Mule slurping coffee from the big tin cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that. A mule drinking coffee!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally found somebody that likes Bonnie's coffee. As they move past, they see Bush standing there..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ya'll better hush, that's old Bush. Carl eyes him. Gary and the others throw curious glances as they head into the diner. Carl stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey.. (NO RESPONSE) I'm talking to you.. Carl picks up a handful of gravel, tosses some over nonchalantly in Bush's direction. Bush ignores it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We know about you. You stay out of this diner. There's women and children here and we don't want you around them. Bush stands to mount up, never turning around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better hear me. I see you here again, I'll.. Hey! Hey! Hearing the hollering, Tom looks up from the pick-up. Carl throws a stone, harder this time to get Bush's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . But the rock misses Bush and hits Mule, startling him. Old instincts kick in and he has a VIOLENT FIT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit.. Carl moves up to try and calm him.. .as Bush tries to ease Mule down the cart hitch grinds a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in Mule's hind-quarter. Mule whinnies painfully, slowly surrendering. As Carl steps up, Bush yanks the BRAKE HANDLE off the cart and hits Carl in the chest. Air explodes from Carl as he gasps with pain. Before he can move, Bush hits him again in the same place. Carl wants to hit back but he has no air. Lightning quick, Bush steps back and hits Carl again in the exact same place. Carl falls like a bag of bones. He looks up and sees Bush towering over him with a terrible bottled up darkness in him. It has all happened so fast it feels like an awful dream to Carl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy! Wild with fear, Bonnie and Tom run toward Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop it!! Get away! Gary, the Worker burst from the diner but see the brake handle in Bush's hand and slow down. Bush comes to himself, sees everyone staring, sees Carl in tears, and now Tom and Bonnie, trying to get him away.. Gary and the others slowly move toward Bush. More patrons step out from the diner. Buddy races up, sees Mule bleeding, and eyes Bush as he grabs the reins and leads Mule down Main street, still holding the brake handle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll kill him! Bonnie shushes him softly as Carl moans in pain. Tom stares after Bush, mirroring his father's hatred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - DAY 23 An EMPTY CASKET, awaits its passenger in a small but serviceable funeral hall. Through the office door, FRANK QUINN sits at his desk, his head completely buried behind a paper that he shakes hard every few seconds. His feet are up on the desk revealing a pair of lovely burgundy silk socks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME/OFFICE - SAME 24 Frank's hand slips the flask next to his coffee cup into a drawer when he HEARS the front door open. But his face remains hidden as Buddy enters. Buddy is troubled by the fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank? (off Frank's grunt) There was a fight. It was..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .let me guess. Hmm. Carl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well yeah but this time it was with that old man Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Old man? (DISTANTLY HOPEFUL) Is there a body?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, the old man did the beating. Never seen anything like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Social event of the year and I missed it. Frank lowers the paper so just his eyes appear. He has no southern accent and doesn't look small town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Read the paper today? (off Buddy's no) Something strange is happening in the world right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People are dying in bunches. (off Buddy's look) Everywhere. But here. He puts the paper down and studies his socks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder what the odds are of a funeral home going broke? I mean you have a business everybody on earth needs, you can't make that work, it's got to be you right? And yet.. I don't know.. what do you do when people won't die?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Onethingabout Chicago, people knowhowto die; they drown, get runover,shot, whatever it takes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We get it done down here, we're just not in a hurry about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's them or us. Frank sighs and stares forlornly out at a casket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might know someone who is looking for a funeral. Frank's eyes crawl over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ./INT. FRONTAGE ROAD/FRANK'S CAR - DAY 30 The Quinn Funeral Home Packard Hearse makes it way down the road. Frank drives as Buddy searches ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much did he have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was all wadded up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ooo, hermit money. That's good. Buddy sees Bush's signs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There it is..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FRANK'S CAR/FRONTAGE ROAD - DAY 31 They stop at Bush's sign: 'No Damn Trespassing." Frank squints up at the old shack and doesn't like what he sees at all. Buddy opens his door but Frank doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been wanting a shot at sales..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As of right now, you're on commission. (off Buddy's look) Remember; foot in the door, establish trust, and drop the hammer. Buddy hesitates, crawls out, and eyes the shack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd feel better if you'd go too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No doubt but if you don't do this by yourself, you won't know if you're any good. And you'll never be any good if you don't know you are. Go get him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S SHACK - DAY 32 As Buddy uneasily approaches the shack, he feels the beautiful stillness and mystery of the place. He KNOCKS timidly on the door, pressing an ear to listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Nothing. He shoots a look back to the hearse - miles away, and knocks a little louder. Nothing. He inches to the window and peeks in one of the remaining glass panes then starts to slide away..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Buddy spins and discovers Bush standing on the ground behind him, his shotgun barrel pointed between Buddy's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want to see in my house, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Bush blows away several windowpanes and re-aims at Buddy's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's it look? Buddy closes his eyes, his last words are for his wife..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Katie.. It makes Bush peek out from behind the barrel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You was at the church with your wife and baby. Buddy opens his eyes and can't believe he is still alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? They stand there while Buddy thinks..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yeah, I heard.. you wanted a funeral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Funeral?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. I work at uh.. I work at.. (tries to think of it) .Quinn Funeral Home. I thought I could help you. Bush glances at his blown out window: 'Damn'. He lowers his gun, walks up onto the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like rabbit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Bush goes inside. Buddy looks desperately back at the hearse but can't see Frank. He doesn't know whether to run for it or not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S SHACK - DAY 33 The shack is spare as a monk's chamber but has wonderful HAND MADE FURNITURE in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down. There is only chair at the table so Buddy dumps the glass off a small stool under the window and sits down low. The wonder of not being dead makes him look at everything with new eyes. On a window sill he sees a beautiful little CARVED MULE emerging from a block of wood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Bush is at the stove tending to a iron skillet of rabbit pieces covered with bacon and white gravy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's how you put things together, see? Some things go, some things never will. Indians said that everything spoke to them. That's how they made medicine and knew what to eat. Things talked to them clear as we talk. You believe that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .. I don't know, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you don't listen you won't hear nothing. Bush puts the big skillet on the table and sits down. Buddy is so low he can look under the table and sees how the table legs run right into the top without screws or nails.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you make this furniture, sir? Never seen any like it. Can't even tell what's holding it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Magic. Buddy looks up. Bush is dead serious. The word lingers. Finally..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. Well. Sir, if you do want to plan for a funeral service, which I hope will be a long long time away, we'd treat you with respect and offer a good..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd everybody say about what happened in town?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That crazy old son of a bitch tried to beat a man to death for no reason? That it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Buddy is caught off guard by Bush's lucid candor and finds himself automatically responding differently to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's two sides to every story. As Bush puts some rabbit on Buddy's old yellowed plate..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People say that. But they don't mean it. They think what they think and they don't want to know anything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir, but I think people are so scared of what they don't know that they make things up to feel better about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like life after dying. Heaven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope that part's true, don't you? (BEAT) But I don't think we know the actual truth about much of anything. I know I don't. I'm just guessing most of the time. Bush gives Buddy a closer look and motions for him to try the rabbit. Fearing the worst, Buddy bends into the steam, takes a cautious bites and mutters with shocked surprise..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lord, that's good..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You boys been coming out here to throw rocks through my window for
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ya'll know lots of stories about me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir, I guess, but..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd rather not. Bush eases forward, his eyes slit. The old Bush is back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I rather you did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (startled/leans back) Well. When I was kid I heard you killed some men in a fist fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that all? Bush leans back stone-faced. In the silence, Buddy looks over again at the wondrous carving of the mule on the window sill, at the big ears and long face that are being born from the rough block. It makes him smile. But when he glances back, Bush is staring a hole through him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buddy Robinson, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if I need you -- I know where you are. It sounds almost like a threat. It shorts Buddy out. He stops eating and realizes that Bush has taken another turn and that he's been dismissed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S SHACK - DAY 34 Buddy heads to the hearse, glancing back over his shoulder. As he recalls his encounter, he stops, looking back at the shack. The old legend has gotten deep under his skin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S LAND/FIELD 35A The morning sun breaks over the mountains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S SHACK - MORNING 36 Bush is on the porch, straining boiled herbs, grass, and bark into a jar. There is something not right with him and he knows it. While the medicine cools he looks out across the mountain and draws a deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - MORNING 37 A well crafted live-in home doubling as a funeral parlor. A sign, 'QUINN FUNERAL HOME', hangs from the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Oh yes Ma'am, I do respect your wishes but you see..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME/FRANK'S OFFICE - SAME 38 Frank is looking a little hung over. Buddy walks in. Frank points at the phone and rolls his blood shot eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .state law requires.. No ma'am, we can't bury him under the house.. There is a loud KNOCK at the door. Buddy goes to get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME/FRONT DOOR - DAY 39 Buddy swings the door open. Bush is standing there. Buddy leans back unconsciously, not knowing what to expect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Well just for argument's sake, Ma'am, how would we get the casket under the house? No casket?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like to come in, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Bush stares suspiciously into the room then back at Buddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) But you have to have a container of some kind, Ma'am for decency and uh, sanitation. Bush enters the Funeral Home. As Buddy starts to close the door, Bush catches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - CONTINUOUS 40 Frank is still on the phone and pouring himself a drink from the flask into his coffee cup in the drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Ma'am, but there's lots of natural things that aren't decent. (listens, eyes widen) He did what?! Good God. No, Ma'am, I didn't know that about your husband. Well, yeah now I understand why you want him under the house but still.. The phone goes dead. FRANK sighs as Bush walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank Quinn, Mr. Bush. Frank takes a quick swallow from his cup to fortify himself, then jumps up, smiling, and goes to Bush with his hand out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in, come in, pleasure. Coffee? As Bush shakes Frank's hand, he stares into him, taking everything in, his bloodshot eyes, the wrinkled shirt beneath his suit, his breath. Frank feels downright naked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You from anywhere?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little bit of everywhere, I guess. Get him a chair, Buddy! Buddy stands behind the waiting chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Bush scrapes up a different chair. Frank goes behind the desk. Buddy pulls up a chair. Bush reaches into his coat and pulls out the wad of hermit money and lays it on the desk. Frank does something phenomenal. He ignores the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can we help you, sir? Bush gives Buddy a look, then looks back at Frank who steadfastly refuses to look at the ball of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm after a funeral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, are you in luck. (GETTING UP) Follow me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - DAY 41 Frank and Buddy stand with Bush in a room dedicated to sales. Three caskets are lined up for display. All tanks. Bush steps up to a cheap cloth covered box, bangs it with his knuckles, and scowls. Frank points to a wooden casket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solid pecan, steel handles.. Bush eyes it, repulsed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Bush is an amazing carpenter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget the box. What else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you want, flowers..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burial plot..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A service?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of party?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Funeral party. Stumped for once in his life, Frank looks at Buddy. Then years of honed instincts surge back to life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME/OFFICE - DAY 42 As they come back into the office..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I want to be there. Frank goes behind his desk. Buddy and Bush start to sit..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will be, I guarantee it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to be there now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to be at your funeral.. party.. alive? (off Bush's nod) But.. it's not a funeral if you're not, you know, deceased..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on now, it's a detail, we can look at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretty big detail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Frank cuts Buddy a look then smiles at Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you'd like to have a funeral party while you're alive so you can go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes or no?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Buddy is lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buddy, get some paper. We need to make of list of who Mr. Bush wants to invite.. As Buddy starts to get up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down. Buddy sits right down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want everybody to come who's got a story to tell about me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That probably covers 4 counties.. Bush shoots him a look. Frank shoots him a look. Buddy thinks about how great an outdoor life would be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I want 4 counties worth of people at the party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, sir, the thing is, how would you get people to come and tell stories about you that I'm guessing might get them, you know.. shot? Bush scoops up the ball of money and heads out. Now all Frank can see is the money, leaving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what, you go ahead, don't worry about it, we'll think of something. A couple of ideas just came to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - DAY 43 As Bush starts out the open door, he nearly bumps into Buddy's wife, Kathryn, and MATTIE DARROW. Mattie is carrying Kathryn and Buddy's baby boy. Frank sees Mattie and flicks his hair back nervously and quickly brushes his teeth with his finger as.. .Bush gives Mattie a glance and tries to be invisible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix?! Feigning deafness, Bush walks on. Sensing something, Kathryn takes the baby so Mattie can go after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix! Say hello to me! Frank, eyes wide with surprise, mouths, "Felix?". Bush's shoulder hunch then fall as he turns. He looks into her, taking everything in. When he speaks his eyes and voice are soft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Mattie. Buddy comes out, surprised to see Mattie and Bush together. Frank walks up behind him and scowls. Kathryn steers them back inside to give Mattie privacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heard you moved off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been back a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look like you always did. He abruptly rips himself away and is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - DAY 44 Buddy and Frank are peeking out the window. They see Mattie standing alone as Bush walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How would she know him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) It's none of our business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So? We got to know. Kathryn shakes her head and goes back outside. FRANK has another look at Mattie then lets the curtain fall back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See the size of that thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean, what? Goddamn ball of money! He wants a party with pink balloons on his ears, we're gonna give it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sold 26 of the ugliest cars ever made one December, in Chicago, with wind blowing so hard up my ass I was farting snow flakes in July so don't tell me we can't do this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the last "but" I want to hear out of you. You're a salesman now, sell!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking out again) She called him Felix.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - DAY 45 Kathryn rocks the baby in a carriage. Mattie is beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A thousand years ago he was the most interesting man I'd ever met.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was. And I don't mean just the way he looked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no, listen, he was beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you serious?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most people are just laid out nice and simple, you know? You always know what they're thinking and where you are with them. But he was this.. big old cave that went deeper and deeper. You'd never get to the end of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good Lord, you had a crush on him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the girls did. I know he's something wild that crawls out of the hills once in a while and gets into trouble now but there's still nobody like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S BARN - MORNING 46 Bush comes out of the barn. Frank and Buddy are there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have a plan. All we need is a little bit of your time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seeing it is better than hearing about it. Bush looks at the hearse, back at Buddy and Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much is it gonna cost?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you say anything about money? (touches his own chest) I didn't say anything about money. (TO BUSH) If we can't get you what you want you don't owe us anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HEARSE - DAY 47 Frank, Buddy, and Bush ride in the front seat of the hearse. They are together but in very different worlds. They don't even look at each other when they talk. Buddy is lost in serious thought. Frank is preoccupied about the deal and driving too fast. Bush is scrunched up to the door. He is going much faster than he is used to going. He kinda likes it and kinda doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It moves, don't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fancy car for the dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't buy it for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (out of nowhere) We say that funerals are "For the Living" but we forget what that means sometimes, I guess. (to Bush but almost to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was thinking about your funeral party before I went to sleep last night and I think I understand it a little now. When I was a kid, my folks where killed in a bad car wreck and the people at the funeral home... they did the impossible as far as I was concerned. I don't know what I would've done without them. And I remember wishing that my mother and daddy were there to see how beautiful they made everything. Frank is hearing this for the first time and is shocked. Bush glances softly at Buddy then looks out the side window at the world rushing by too fast. All at once he gives in to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TOWN STREET - DAY 48 The hearse pulls up on main street. Frank, Buddy, and Bush get out and head toward Feldman's Clothing Store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FELDMAN'S CLOTHING STORE- DAY 48A Frank and Buddy enter the store and find MR. FELDMAN and a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: setting up a large camera and backdrop. As they turn to show Bush what is happening they see him go by the window outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's he going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TOLLERUDE'S BARBER SHOP - DAY 50 A barber's drape falls over BUSH who is seated in a chair. Frank and Buddy rush in. The barber, an anxious Mr. Tollerude, pumps Bush's chair upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish you wouldn't do that yet. Bush gives him the hairy eyeball then speaks to Mr. Tollerude, a clear threat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't leave me naked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Bush, you can get all the hairs cut you want after we take your picture, I'll pay for it. Mr. Tollerude doesn't know whether to cut or not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why you want my picture made?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what we're trying to tell you. We're gonna run an ad in some papers about your party and put up posters of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you want me to look like this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's how people recognize you, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you want as many people to come as possible so..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So a crazy old nutter draws more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Basically. Don't you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you ever say what you mean? Bush rips the bib off as Tollerude whooshes him to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FELDMAN'S CLOTHING STORE 51 Bush is seated in front of a backdrop painted with a bridge, a swan, and a pond. The Photographer is trying to tidy up Bush without offending him. As he walks back to camera, Bush roughs himself up and looks truly wild. Buddy snickers. When the Photographer gets back to the camera, he cocks his head, what?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it. (leans in to Buddy) I'd go see that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TOLLERUDE'S BARBERSHOP - DAY 52 Mr. Tollerude, nervous as hell, brings Bush up from his reclining position and turns the chair to the mirror. Bush studies his well trimmed hair and beard for a moment. It's impossible to tell what his thoughts are as he looks into his own eyes. Buddy and Frank are in the mirror too, staring at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn. You look pretty good.. Bush suddenly gets up and nods at Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's paying. As Bush blows out the door, Mr. Tollerude leans against the chair with relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FELDMAN'S CLOTHING STORE - DAY 53 Bush stands in front of a full length mirror. He has on a decent black suit, pinned to be hemmed, and a plain white shirt, open at the collar. It is a startling change. But we still can't tell what he is thinking. Buddy is staring at him with honest disbelief. Frank is quietly trying to get Mr. Feldman to lower the price for the suit. He looks over and double-takes Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son of a bitch, it's almost worth it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't know you, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe the Devil won't either. Might work out. (TO FRANK) Where's the shoes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, normally people don't wear shoes in a casket so.. (off Bush's scowl) .what are you, about a 10D?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FELDMAN'S CLOTHING STORE - MOMENTS LATER 54 Buddy stands beside Frank who is still trying to get a deal on the clothes. Bush walks up with two pairs of pants and two new shirts, puts them on the counter, gives Frank a hard look, and walks away. Frank looks down at the clothes, over at Buddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretty optimistic taking a change of clothes to the grave. (calls over his shoulder) How you set for underwear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Don't wear none.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One question too many.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HEARSE - DAY 56 Everyone is back in the hearse. Something is eating at Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mean to be nosey but uh.. how do you know Mattie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's a peach. Frank and Buddy cut Bush a look. He looks ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We had a go. Frank nearly drives off the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME/ FRANK'S ROOM - NIGHT 57 Late night Poker. Cigarette smoke drifts into the air. Frank, Carl, Rev. Horton, Mattie, and RAY, a banker, are at the table. Ray has the untouchable presence of someone privileged which appears to be driving Frank up a tree tonight. Horton gathers up his winnings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The Lord loves a cheerful giver.."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh please.. you think the Lord's taking sides in a poker game in a funeral home? Horton shrugs and points to the divine evidence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If He is, the Divine's cheating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't agree with me Ray, it makes me doubt myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Ray sighs and studies his perfectly cut nails.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would have turned down your loan if you were my own dear mother, Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You made my point and don't even know it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, would you two stop it! You're worse than two old women.. Ray shrugs, sweetly blase. Frank tries to rein in his temper for her. The loss of the hand is especially hard on Carl who has only a couple of dollars left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What were you doing with that old bastard in town today, anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes. Buying him clothes, getting him a haircut..on credit. Frank shoots him a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Took out ads in a bunch of papers too, something about a party?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, I love small towns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That hermit, what's his name..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a knowing look at Mattie) "Felix" Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're giving him a party?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A funeral party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you're drinking is not being good to you at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is a funeral party?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, the man wants to be at his own funeral. What can I say? I'd like to be at my funeral so I could tell my ex-wife to kiss my..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What makes you think she'd show up for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because, Dear, vultures are constitutionally unable to ignore the dead. Mattie grins which delights Frank, no end. Horton stops counting his money and stares at Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's that big wad of money of his you're after. There is a crack in Ray's disinterest that he tries to hide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What money is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix has money? Everyone is looking at Frank but he shuffles the cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He came to see me, wanting a funeral, had a big old greasy ball of money. Talked like he thought he could buy his way to heaven with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much has he got? Maybe he can. Hearing that Bush wants or needs a real funeral Mattie is suddenly truly concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he sick, Gus? Horton shrugs. Frank notes the concern and doesn't like it. Carl coughs and his ribs make him break out into a sweat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you one damn thing, ain't nobody gonna go to a funeral for that son of a bitch. Mattie gives Carl a look
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Language..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They might. He's inviting everyone who has a story about him to come. You could tell about him kicking your ass, Carl. Carl looks at Frank as if he wants to cold cock him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Old man is going to ride the Weird Train right into the ground, isn't he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wouldn't you like to know what everybody says about you behind your back, Ray? (off his look) Yeah, probably not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I already know way more about people than I need to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or want to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's play some cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh for God's sake, face it Frank, you're broke. This is not about cards. It's a declaration meant to embarrass Frank in front of everyone. Frank feels their eyes on him as he starts to pull off his watch. Ray waves it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please. I've won that 4 times already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's who has it last that counts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say what you want but if there hadn't been anybody there the other day he would've killed me. And I guarantee you it wouldn't have been his first time. It sounds true and everyone is quiet except Mattie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody knows you started it. (off his glare) Don't look at me like that. I remember when you were born. You were the sweetest little boy. What is wrong with you? Momentarily shamed, Carl's face softens and we can see a better man there. He struggles to hold on to it but..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I made a mistake. But there's a line.. and he crossed it.. and everybody knows that too. Ya'll go on and have a party with the devil for his money but I'll dance on his grave someday. Carl snatches his few dollars up and heads out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You kind of hate to admit it when it comes to Carl but he's got a point. You don't know what Bush is doing. What if he just wants to get everybody in one place so he can turn his shotgun on them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wouldn't..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I looked in his eyes. The truth is nobody knows what he's capable of. Maybe even he doesn't know. She looks into him. Frank starts to deal the cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead and lay your watch down, Frank. But I am going to keep it this time, alright, on principle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got an idea. Let's try something different. (TO RAY) The cards in your sock? Leave'em there. Everyone freezes. Ray shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you trying to pull now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really think you're that good that nobody sees?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sees what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cheat at everything you do. Even at the bank, you loan people just enough to get'em deeper in so you can foreclose on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a pathetic man. And a goddamn..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I? Then stand up and roll down your socks. (a deep dark look) Stand up or I'll stand you up. Ray looks around the table and suddenly realizes that he is irreversibly exposed and alone. The sound of Frank's chair scraping the floor makes him jerk up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks out, trying to find his old confident rhythm and failing. Everyone sits in uneasy silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - NIGHT 58 Horton waves and walks out, leaving the door open. Frank walks Mattie to the door, helping with her coat, trying to work up his nerve to say..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll walk you home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure? (off her firm nod) You're not going to play anymore, are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I don't know. Thank you for inviting me though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry about the..we don't always fight, okay, we do, but he's had that coming for..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not that. I just..(trails off)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You came because you don't know what to do with yourself. (off her look) I slept on the same side of the bed my whole life, right? But after my wife left me, I switched sides, just like that, and never been able to go back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When someone you love is gone, you can pour everything, even a lifetime of things into the place where they were but it's still always empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He sees that her thoughts are not with him at all but a million miles away. She hardly glances up when she says..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Night. He stares after her, wishing that she could see him the way he sees her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .BUSH'S SHACK - NIGHT 60 Dim lamp light glows. We see Bush sitting on the edge of the bed wiping the sweat from his face with a sheet. He looks up at the picture of the beautiful woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .BUDDY'S HOUSE - NIGHT 61 Buddy sits in the dark, rocking his son who is asleep. A small lamp casts a shadow across them. Kathryn comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't hear him wake up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything's all right, hon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad you don't know how quick it can change. She gently kisses his arm and the baby's head. Buddy looks at her, haunted by the very possibility of their absence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET - DAY 62 Mattie is standing on the sidewalk at Feldman's store with her coat collar pulled up against the cold, giving someone we can't see a bemused affectionate scolding..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good Lord. Have you completely lost your mind? (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont`d) Straighten up for heaven's sake before somebody throws a net over you! But she smiles in spite of herself, glances around to see if anyone was watching and moves discretely on. As she does we see that she was talking to a striking WANTED POSTER of a wild man sitting in front of a pond, a swan, and a bridge. The text reads: 41.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: MYSTERIOUS HERMIT OF CALEB COUNTY THROWS A FUNERAL PARTY

direction.raw_text: . MUSIC! FOOD! STORIES! DANCING!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WCGM RADIO STATION - NIGHT 63 A tiny PLACE, cramped with radio gear. Buddy and Frank peer through a glass window into a small control booth.(We will cut back and forth between the glass) Buddy is having misgivings about being here. But Frank gives the thumbs up to the young WCGM ANNOUNCER in the booth, a hopeful kid with a smooth voice and dreams of the big-time. The Announcer hands Bush a set of headphones. Bush is wearing his new clothes and truly looks like a different man. Bush is puzzled by the headset. The kid takes it and clamps it onto Bush's head. He starts to yank them off then hears a song playing inside his head and loves it. But now the announcer cuts the record off and Bush scowls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Friends, we have a treat for you today on WCGM. Our special guest is going to tell us about an event that everyone is talking about. And here he is, Mr. Felix Bush, the mysterious hermit of Caleb County! How are you today, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am. Bush is surprised by the sound of his own voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So tell us, sir, exactly how did you come up with the idea of having a funeral party before you die?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dreamed it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would I make that up? Two seconds of dead air as the announcer finds his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Now I have to say that you don't look quite like you do on the posters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got pruned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you're a bit of a local legend, sir. I was a little nervous about our interview. I've heard some pretty wild stories..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well uh, just.. from what I understand, you want everyone who has a story about you to come and tell it. Is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You come and tell yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Now how long have you been living out there by yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MATTIE DARROW HOUSE - NIGHT/CONTINUOUS 64 Mattie is cutting the stems of some lovely yellow flowers and arranging them in a vase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: some years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: years with nobody to talk to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) First 38 are the hardest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mattie grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WCGM - CONTINUOUS 65 ANNOUNCER But why would you do that, Mr. Bush, shut yourself off like that? Frank isn't happy with this but Buddy wants to hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come to the funeral and maybe you'll find out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard it here on WCGM, folks, find out the answer to the mystery February 16..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One more thing, boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and Buddy tense. What's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DARROW HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 6 6 Mattie tenses at the sound in Bush's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Gonna be a drawing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) What kind of drawing, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You buy a ticket for $5.00 The day of the funeral we draw names. Then when I die, the winner gets my place, 300 acres of timber that hasn't been touched in 40 years. Mattie accidentally cuts a bloom off of a flower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WCGM - SAME 67 Dead air. The kid, Frank, and Buddy are all staring at Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For 5 dollars?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Send it to the Quinn Funeral Home. Frank's eyes light up like fiery pinwheels and he almost yelps! Buddy looks oddly perplexed and sad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard him! If you want a chance to win 300 acres of virgin timber worth thousands and thousands of dollars, send 5 dollars along with your name and address to.. (off Frank waving and pointing to himself) Frank Quinn at Quinn Funeral Home. As the Announcer begins a song, Bush moves his head in time with the music. Frank and Buddy rush into the control booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could almost kiss you on the mouth!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take a ticket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're betting on a man dying..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't mean it like..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, it's his idea! They look at Bush who has taken off the headset and looking at it like he wants to take it home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's what you want, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buy a ticket, son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DARROW HOUSE - SAME 6 8 Mattie puts the vase of flowers on table with a group of family photographs. The picture beside the vase is the SAME PHOTOGRAPH of the beautiful woman that Bush has. Is it Mattie? It looks a little like her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PHOTO: The BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOMAN stares at us as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: that we are now looking at the identical photo tacked to Bush's wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S BARN - LATE DAY 70 Bush starts out of the barn, draws back, and peeks through the wall boards: A FIGURE approaches. He jerks..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mattie walking
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mattie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix? Mattie enters, straining to see into the barn. Her eyes adjust to find him standing near Mule. She is startled and pleased by his new do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at you. I wondered if you were still under that beard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wasn't nowhere else to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard you on the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've gotten downright chatty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I reckon so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is nice. I drove by a few times after I got back but..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to see it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want me to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S LAND - DAY 71 The first stop on the tour is a small fenced grave site near the shack. Three grave markers with names carved into them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Bush is squatting down staring at the markers. Mattie stands close beside him. Since his attention is elsewhere she looks at him in an unguarded way. Her mind is full of questions, old and new.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You always know where you stand with a dog. Want to lay here with them someday if they'll have me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S LAND - DAY/LATER 72 Mattie and Bush walks side by side through the last of the glimmering light and shadows beneath the trees. It is a chilly and Mattie's cheeks are flushed. She is enchanted by the place. Bush tries to hide how winded he is..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It really is beautiful. Probably looked like this everywhere a hundred years ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You leave things alone, they know what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Ma'am. I don't know what to do about anything much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been alone a long time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some people are more suited to it than others, I reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's funny cause I never thought that it'd suit you. I knew you wouldn't be like anybody else but.. no one to talk to, no one to.. be with.. never. He looks into her then looks away at something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How you sleeping these days, girl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How am I what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sleep good?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not lately. How'd you know? He veers off the path and pulls up a plant and brings it back to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chamomile, it's good when the nights get long. Helps you nod off. She takes it and smiles up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want to go on a ways? MATTIE Yes. BUSH Would you stay for supper? MATTIE I don't want to be any trouble. BUSH A supper guest every 30-40 years is not much trouble, Girl. MATTIE Alright then. He holds out his arm. BUSH Better stay close, some big old wild cats been eating my chickens.. She looks around and takes his arm. BUSH .or maybe it was me.. She snorts and slaps his arm but doesn't let go.. 73 OMITTED 73 48.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUSH'S SHACK - NIGHT 74 They enter the dark room together. Bush lights a lantern, gets a chair from a corner and holds it out for her. She sits and watches him check a cast iron pot on the warm stove and put a log on the fire. She notices the beautiful table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You always were good with your hands. He puts a glass of tea in front of her and sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You still play the piano?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I teach a few girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got a good feeling when you played. Remember that time you was playing and the lamp burned out? And you went right on in the dark? I hear that song sometimes at night. She shrugs shyly and sips the tea. Seconds tick by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure is quiet out here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cocks his head) What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said it's.. (stops/gets the joke) I tried to write you at times but I didn't know what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. I heard you married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was a Doctor; a real good man. We lived in St. Louis for awhile. He died unexpectedly about a year ago. I came back here because.. I have no idea why. (sips tea/thinks) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The list of people who are gone is getting longer and longer and sometimes I feel like all I'm doing is waiting for my name to come up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a tender heart, always did. She gives him a curious look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't wait for anything, Mattie. Close your eyes, hold your breath.. stay in one spot your whole life, but you're still moving, like the world's moving under you. There's no waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there's no getting over some things either, is there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reckon not, Little Bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Little Bit?! Oh my God, nobody's called me that in.. But suddenly she is lifted from the chair as if by strong ropes. She stares at the wall as she walks toward Bush's bed. Bush is stricken and white. He would stop her if he could but it is too late. She walks right up to the picture at the edge of the lamp light and stares into it as if it is a mirage that will disappear if she blinks. Finally she whirls and looks at him, her face a tortured mask. A strangled sob escapes her. He gets up and stands there staring at the floor. Suddenly she is moving toward him and then past him and out the door. Her shadow merges with the darkness. Bush stands with his head down, staring into oblivion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME/OFFICE - DAY 78 Buddy comes in frowning and lugging a heavy mail sack. What the hell? He looks up and sees more sacks dumped on the desk. Frank is grinning and ripping open envelopes from the sacks and each one has 5 dollars in it! Buddy looks down and sees even more mail sacks on the floor!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, kid!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah! But, but it's not our money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well yeah, no, but some of it's gonna be! We're putting this thing on! Frank rips open two more envelopes and dollar bills rain down to the floor. He's beside himself. Buddy eyes him warily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He should be here. I'm gonna go get him. They lock eyes. Frank finally tosses him the hearse keys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME/OFFICE - DAY 80 Buddy, Frank, and Bush are staring reverently at the money stacked across the desk and the full paper sacks all around the desk. Bush eyes Buddy who is still quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know exactly how much your land's worth but looks to me like you could get maybe 10 times that or more. I don't know what to do with it. I mean it's yours to do with what you want but I'm getting a little nervous about it. Never thought I'd see enough money to make me nervous. We should probably talk about the price for everything, the clothes, the ads, the food and drink for the party, the music.. our fee for everything, we'll be fair about that, I'm not worried about it. Bush is looking at Buddy who is looking across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think, boy? Buddy jerks, looks at Frank, at Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Money makes people do funny things. Frank scowls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you should probably put it in the bank, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Ray is not.. (off Bush's look) I mean, if it was my money I'd put it in a bank out of town so everyone didn't know my business. This bank here, you can't trust, that's all I'm saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I trust you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every name, every dollar, is right there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not what I asked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've done a hell of a job for you. I don't see why..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Bush, I didn't mean to imply..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've sold horses, cars, houses, hell, pocket watches pinned to the inside of my coat. I'm not ashamed of it. I don't rob banks, don't cheat at cards, and I sleep all right the nights I sleep. What was the question..?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They goddamn.. He nods at the money and suddenly becomes the "other" Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take out for the expenses you've already had and give me the receipts. As the bills come in for things, give them to me and I'll pay them. Put this money in a box and the boy and I'll take it someplace in the morning. Whatever new comes in, keep it in the bottom of one of them ugly caskets in there 'till I come get it. After the party, name a fair price for what you've done and we'll settle up. (WALKING OUT) I'll be at the car. After he's gone, Frank and Buddy stare at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it just me or is he extremely fucking articulate when he wants to be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know who's selling who what anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not clear, is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not only that but something feels really wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on. I told you that you were working on commission..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So whatever our end of this is, you get a piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A piece?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Half. It could help set you up, Buddy. So whatever feels wrong is gonna feel right pretty damn quick,okay? We just have to close it out. From here on, watch me, do what I do, and we'll be fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wants you to go with him to take this money somewhere which means that it's you he trusts. And that's fine because I trust you too. Just don't trust him, okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm lost again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, that funny feeling you have.. I have it too. And it's not funny. So go along, be friendly, but that's it. (BEAT) There's a euphoria that comes with closing a deal, Buddy, and the bigger the deal, the higher you get. It's better than anything. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the critical time is just before it closes. It's like a witching hour and everything tries to come apart. We're not going to let that happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now go. (as Buddy starts out) You know.. I always wondered why you wanted to work here. I thought you could do a lot better. (off Buddy's look back) I didn't know about your folks, I'm really sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. He goes on. Frank turns and flips through a large stack of bills, hungrily entranced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUDDY'S HOUSE/BEDROOM - NIGHT 8 1 Buddy's son is crying his heart out. Kathryn comes in unbuttoning her blouse, picks him up, sits down, slips her blouse off her shoulder, brings the boy to her breast and voila, his sorrow miraculously vanishes. Buddy appears in the doorway, his eyes soft with love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might have a crying fit coming on too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Feeling a little weepy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You boys..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (leans against door frame) I can maybe do something really good for us, Katy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You already have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean, money wise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About Mr. Bush?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. I'm getting half of whatever we make off of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So why aren't you happy about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't know I wasn't. (off her look) I was happy for a minute. And then the whole thing of making a carnival out of a person's death, I don't know if it's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it what he wants?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He says it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are not responsible for what other people do, Buddy, just you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. You're always right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least I am when I'm half naked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MATTIE'S HOUSE - NIGHT 82 A very determined little GIRL is working her way through a song on the piano that is unrecognizable in this form, even to her. Mattie sits just behind the girl with tears in her eyes, not really listening. On the table beside the piano is a stack of picture albums and old yellowed newspaper articles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MORNING 83 Sitting in the hearse outside of Bush's shack, Buddy watches Bush get in the car with his shotgun. There is a big wooden box of money on the seat between them. Bush props his shotgun against it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where to, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: North.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (starting the hearse) How far?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Till I say, son. Buddy gives him an uneasy look and pulls off down the tree- lined path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROAD - DAY 84 The hearse slips around the narrow road that cuts through miles of farm land lying fallow in the winter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HEARSE - DAY 85 Buddy looks out at the highway. He is driving slow. Bush is leaning against the money, thinking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much further now? Bush waves him on. Buddy scowls then decides to get serious about this. He presses on the accelerator and the hearse takes off down the highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - DAY 86 Frank is hopelessly lost in a sea of envelopes. The phone is ringing off the hook, there are full sacks around him, and some Reporter is trying to take a picture through the front window. Frank scowls and lowers the blinds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MATTIE'S HOUSE - DAY 87 Frank is at Mattie's door entranced by the troubled but beautiful piano music coming from inside. It stops abruptly when he knocks. In seconds, Mattie appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Mattie. He looks almost boyish and bashful as he drinks her in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was that you? It was really..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a surprise.
direction.name: direction
